pages.title: Accessibility testing workflow
pages.body:
Automated checks

Run axe-core in CI via the Storybook test runner and Playwright smoke tests. Automated tooling catches ~30% of issues, so treat it as an early signal rather than a full sign-off.

Manual validation

  1. Navigate the flow using only a keyboard.
  2. Verify focus outlines are visible on light and dark themes.
  3. Test with a screen reader (VoiceOver, NVDA) to ensure labels and announcements make sense.
  4. Confirm color contrast meets WCAG thresholds using the tokens documentation.

pages.title: Accordion
pages.body:
Overview

Accordions help keep long-form content skimmable by showing one section at a time. Keep section titles short and descriptive—people should understand what they gain before expanding.

Reserve accordions for content that benefits from a progressive disclosure pattern (for example FAQs, filter panels, or secondary instructional text). Prefer inline expansion or navigation pages when the content is critical to task completion.

UX Guidelines

  • Limit the number of items to prevent excessive scrolling.
  • If very important content is hidden behind an accordion, reconsider whether it should be default-open.
  • Provide clear feedback for disabled accordion items and explain why they cannot be opened.

Accessibility details

The component follows the WAI-ARIA accordion pattern using roving tab index. Ensure that focus order remains logical, especially when inserting custom interactive controls inside accordion panels. If panels contain forms, confirm that validation states are announced even when the parent item collapses.

pages.title: Button
pages.body:
Overview

Buttons enable people to act on the current page or commit a task. Choose variants intentionally: use the primary button for the most important action on the view and secondary or ghost variants for less prominent actions.

Place destructive actions away from primary CTAs and communicate the outcome in the label (for example, “Delete project”). Avoid using buttons for navigation between pages—prefer links unless the action commits data.

UX Guidelines

Dos

  • Keep labels short, specific, and outcome oriented (verb + noun works well).
  • Use one primary button per surface to avoid competing actions.
  • Group related buttons and maintain consistent spacing between them.

Don’ts

  • Don’t mix different button sizes within the same group.
  • Don’t rely on color alone to communicate destructive actions—pair with iconography or explicit labels.
  • Don’t disable buttons without also communicating why they cannot be used.

Accessibility details

Buttons follow the WAI-ARIA authoring practices for command buttons. Ensure the focus ring remains visible against both light and dark themes and that contrast between text and fill meets WCAG 2.2 AA (4.5:1).

When introducing toggle behavior, set aria-pressed and ensure the state change is announced to assistive technology. If the button triggers a dialog, move focus into the dialog container after activation.

pages.title: Card
pages.body:
Overview

Cards provide a flexible container for summarizing entities such as projects, resources, or announcements. They can include imagery, supporting text, and action buttons. Keep the content hierarchy consistent: header, body, then footer.

When cards act as navigation triggers, mark the interactive flag and ensure the entire card is focusable. Include descriptive text that conveys the destination or action taken.

UX Guidelines

  • Maintain consistent padding and typography across card variants to reinforce familiarity.
  • Align card actions horizontally and prefer primary buttons on the right for left-to-right locales.
  • Use the subtle variant on surfaces that already provide elevation to avoid competing shadows.

Accessibility details

Interactive cards must provide a clear focus state and respond to both click and keyboard activation (Enter/Space). When cards contain nested interactive elements, ensure that the card itself is not focusable to prevent focus traps. Use ARIA labelling if the card’s purpose is not apparent from visible text.

pages.title: Text Field
pages.body:
Overview

Text fields support short responses like names, emails, and search queries. Always pair the input with a visible label to maintain context and ensure accessibility. Use helper text sparingly to clarify formatting expectations or consequences.

When validation fails, present specific error messages and keep helper text visible so people can compare the correct format with the issue.

UX Guidelines

  • Use sentence case labels and avoid punctuation unless the label is a question.
  • Reserve placeholder text for examples, not essential instructions.
  • Align grouped fields to create a predictable scan pattern.

Accessibility details

The component exposes aria-describedby for helper and error content. When the error string changes, screen readers are notified automatically. Keep the helper and error text concise so it remains readable for assistive technology.

pages.title: Color
pages.body:
Palette

We derive product color from @virtual-ds/tokens. Brand blues appear as primary actions, while neutral surfaces provide structure for content.

Use semantic aliases for UI states instead of referencing raw brand values (for example --state-success). Maintain a minimum contrast ratio of 4.5:1 for text on backgrounds.

Theming

Tokens ship with light and dark modes. Apply the correct theme by toggling the data-theme attribute on the document element. Custom themes can be layered by overriding semantic tokens while leaving component tokens intact.

pages.title: Typography
pages.body:
Font stacks

Our sans-serif stack defaults to Inter with system fallbacks:

Use the monospace stack for code snippets, console output, or token names.

Type scale

TokenSizeUsage
--font-size-xs0.75remLegal text, captions
--font-size-sm0.875remInput labels, helper text
--font-size-md1remBody copy
--font-size-lg1.125remSection headings
--font-size-xl1.5remPage titles

Line heights default to --font-line-height-normal. Increase to relaxed for paragraphs over 80 characters wide.

pages.title: Spacing
pages.body:
Scale

Spacing tokens follow a 4px base grid and expose semantic aliases:

TokenValueUsage
--spacing-2xs0.25remCompact gaps between labels and inputs
--spacing-xs0.5remInline spacing for button groups
--spacing-sm0.75remForm field vertical rhythm
--spacing-md1remDefault stack spacing
--spacing-lg1.5remSection padding
--spacing-xl2remLayout gutters

Layout guidelines

  • Align to the baseline grid whenever stacking interactive controls.
  • For page sections, pair padding-block values with the appropriate viewport breakpoints (for example, var(--spacing-xl) on desktop, var(--spacing-lg) on mobile).

pages.title: Form validation
pages.body:
Overview

Form validation should prevent surprises: validate on blur for single fields and on submit for the entire form. Keep people in context by presenting inline errors near the relevant field. Use toast notifications only for submission-level failures.

Checklist

  • Present error messaging directly beneath the field using the error prop on <ui-text-field>.
  • Move focus to the first errored field on submit and ensure the screen reader announces the message.
  • Disable submit buttons only during processing—otherwise provide inline instructions so the user knows how to resolve issues.
